questions.questionText: What region is pain present in?
When do you feel the pain?
Do you experience ankle joint stiffness?
If yes, when?
Do you feel the pain about 4 cm above your heel?
What type of pain do you feel?
Is there evidence of inflammation around the heel?
Do you experience pain during push-off phase of walking?
Does the pain reduce with rest at joint or with the use of NSAIDs?

conditions.name: Achilles Tendon Rupture

questions.questionText: Do you feel the pain about 5cm from your heel?
Do you engage in sports requiring heavy push-offs such as: squash, badminton, football, tennis, netball?
Have you had a previous history of tendinitis?
Did you hear a ripping or popping sensation accompanying the pain at onset?
Did you feel like someone hit you on the heel at the onset of the pain?
Have you self-medicated with local corticosteroids before?

recommended_tests: Check if plantarflexion of the ankle is weak.
Check for palpable gap at the site of the rupture
Thompson’s or Simmond’s Test: Patient lies prone and the calf is squeezed. If tendon is ruptured, the foot will remain still when it ought to contract involuntarily.
confirmation_methods: Radiographic Imaging: Use ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis.

conditions.name: Traction Apophysitis (Sever’s Disease)

questions.questionText: Is pain and tenderness localised to the insertion of the Tendon Achilles?

recommended_tests: Check for density of apophysitis and check for fragmentation of the apophysitis.

questions.questionText: Where do you feel the pain?
Do you have painful bumps on your heel?
Do you experience this more during cold weather times?
Do you wear high-heeled shoes?

conditions.name: Plantar Fasciitis

questions.questionText: Do you experience pain on heel or sole with standing and/or walking?
Is this pain most prominent at the heel?
Is the onset of pain sudden or gradual?

metadata.notes: Ask if patient has just recently changed their footwear

questions.questionText: Is pain worse when you first get up in the morning?

metadata.notes: Though this is not in every case

questions.questionText: Do you feel the pain more when you get up after you have been sitting for a long time?
Is there tenderness at the medial aspect beneath the heel / mid-foot?

recommended_tests: Confirmation using ultrasound to check for thickening around the heel.
Doppler test to show increased local blood flow and neovascularisation

questions.questionText: Did you stumble on a stairway, potholes or pavement before the onset of pain?
Have you experienced any twisting or wrenching movement at your ankle joint?
Can you walk with the affected foot and bear weight on it?
Is bruise at sight of injury faint and did it appear slowly?

conditions.name: Acute Injury of Lateral Ligaments

questions.questionText: Is severe pain felt on slight attempt to invert (turn inward) foot?

observations: Palpate the ankle, distally and anteriorly to the lateral malleolus and ask if patient feels more pain. Usually, patient feels more pain on palpation.
Rule out undisplaced fracture of Fibula, tarsal bone, 5th metatarsal bone

conditions.name: Recurrent Lateral Instability

questions.questionText: Have you had a past episode of an ankle sprain?
If yes, have you had experiences like your ankle giving way OR instability when walking on uneven surfaces?

metadata.notes: proceed to special test either ways

recommended_tests: Special Test for Recurrent Lateral Instability

Talar tilt test: The ankle is held in the neutral position, examiner stabilised the tibia just above the ankle and then tries to force the ankle into maximum inversion. The ROM can be measured or compared with the contralateral side.Inversion laxity suggests injury to calcaneofibular and anterior talofibular ligaments (ATFL).

Anterior Drawer Test: Patient sits with knee flexed at 90 deg and ankle in plantarflexion of about 10 deg. The lower leg is stabilised by the examiner and the force patient’s heel forward over the tibia. If positive, the talus can be felt sliding forwards and backwards. Laxity indicates tear of the ATFL.

conditions.name: Deltoid Ligament Tear

questions.questionText: Do you have a previous history of fibular fracture?

observations: Check if foot is everted and externally rotated.
Check for widening of the medial joint space in the mortise view, check if talus is tilted, check for fracture or dislocation of the proximal fibula.

conditions.name: Tears of Inferior Tibiofibular Ligaments

questions.questionText: Did you have an injury that twisted your ankle?
Do you feel pains in front of your ankle?
Is swelling and marked tenderness present directly over the inferior tibiofibular joint?

recommended_tests: Squeeze Test: Compress the leg firmly above the ankle. Test is positive if pain is felt over the syndesmosis.

questions.questionText: Do you play sports?
Any history of fall prior to the onset of the injury?
Did you experience any twisting injury with your ankle going into inversion?
Did you experience a fall with your foot anchored to the ground while your body fell forward?
Is any obvious deformity present in the ankle?
Following the onset of the pain are you able to stand and bear weight on the affected part?

conditions.name: CALCANEAL FRACTURES

questions.questionText: Is the patient osteoporotic?
Did you experience a fall from a height?
Were you involved in a road traffic accident?
Is your foot painful and swollen?

options.value: Does the heel look broad and wide

questions.questionText: Is the surrounding tissue around the heel thick and tender?
Is the normal concavity (hollow) below the lateral malleolus lacking?
Can you invert (turn inward) and evert (turn outward) your foot?
Do you feel intense pain in the foot?
Is bruising and swelling extensive?
Is sensation diminished at the foot?
Do you experience pain on the dorsiflexion of the toes?

observations: Check if two-point discrimination is present.
Check if pain is present on passive movement of the toes

conditions.name: RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

questions.questionText: Do you feel uncomfortable when you wear your shoes?
Since the onset of this discomfort, do you walk less due to the discomfort?
Do you feel pain at your metatarsophalangeal joint (forefoot)?
Is the region of the metatarsophalangeal joint (forefoot) swollen?
Is there tenderness at the metatarsaophalangeal joint (forefoot)?
Do you feel pain when you press or squeeze the forefoot?
Did this pain progress to the entire foot?
Do you experience weakness of your foot muscles?

observations: Prominence of the metatarsal head in the soles (Feels like walking on stones)
Check for osteoporosis, and periarticular erosion at the metatarsophalangeal joint.

conditions.name: RA of Ankle and Hindfoot

questions.questionText: Do you find it increasingly difficult to walk?
Do you experience pain around your ankle?
Is swelling and tenderness present behind the lateral and/or medial malleolus?
Do you find it painful to invert (turn inward) and evert (turn outward) your foot?
Do you find the range of movement limited when you try to invert (turn inward) and evert (turn outward) your foot??
Is a valgus deformity (turning outward of the foot) present?

confirmation_methods: Radiographic confirmation. Check for osteoporosis, erosion of the tarsal and ankle joints and the swelling of soft-tissues.

conditions.name: OSTEOARTHRITIS

questions.questionText: Have you had a previous diagnosis of osteoarthritis of other joints?
Do you have any previous history of the following: malunited fracture, recurrent instability, and avascular necrosis of the talus?
Do you experience pain and stiffness at the ankle joint?
Do you notice this pain more when standing up from rest?
Is the ankle swollen?
Do you experience limitation when bringing the foot upward towards (dorsiflexion) and pushing the foot downward away (plantar flexion) from the shin?

confirmation_methods: Radiographic confirmation – check for joint space narrowing, osteophytes formation, subchondral sclerosis, and cyst formation.
observations: are palpable anterior osteophytes present at the ankle joint
is tenderness present along the anterior joint line.

conditions.name: Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome

questions.questionText: Do you feel numbness, burning and tingling sensation in your foot and/or medial portion of your ankle?
Do you experience weakness in your foot muscles (toe abductors and flexors)?
Do you have a previous history of diabetes or osteoarthritis?
Does your job or daily task involve running, excessive walking and standing?
Do you have a previous history of trauma or dislocation at ankle region?
Is tenderness present behind the medial malleolus?
Do the symptoms you feel worsen with a forceful eversion (turning outward) of the foot OR dorsiflexion (moving foot upwards towards the shin)?
Do you feel a stabbing pain in the medial sole of your foot while walking?
Does the pain get aggravated with walking?
Do you feel night pain that wake you up from sleep?

recommended_tests: Tinel’s sign: Percussion of the tarsal tunnel. Positive if this results in a distal radiation of paraesthesia
Dorsiflexion-Eversion Test: Place the patient’s foot into dorsiflexion and eversion and hold for 5-10 seconds. Positive if patient’s symptom is elicited.
observations: Check for atrophy of the abductor hallucis
Check for the position of the talus and calcaneus
